Intro: A guide to digital design at The Guardian

slides.Text: The Guardian website is made up of a series of fronts and articles.
Fronts are broken down into containers, these allow stories to be organised in a logical manner
Containers are composed of modular blocks of story cards
Cards can hold an image, kicker, headline, standfirst and meta information
Each card type is designed to give a sense of the tone of the story
Thrashers are custom designed containers usually promoting single articles or series (app thrashers are different)
The grid unifies the way we arrange information on all our digital platforms
The desktop grid is based on columns of 60px with 20px gutter
We use 4 fixed grid sizes on large screens Wide — 1300px, LeftCol — 1140px Desktop — 980px, Tablet — 740px
And a fluid grid on mobile devices
Spacing is used intentionally to reference keep the design language consistent across print and digital
The placement of the typography
This alignment is consistent from headlines on cards and container titles to bylines in article pages
The Guardian has two expressions of its brand
The logo and the roundel are always either aligned top right or bottom right
The roundel acts as a simplified expression of the brand — often used to mark the Guardian’s own content on and off platform. For more detailed information please visit theguardian.com/brand-hub
The Guardian has two main typefaces and three additional typefaces
Guardian headline is designed to allow for the optimal reading experience across all platforms and is used across the website and the app for headlines giving them a unique character and voice
Guardian Titlepeice is an accompaniment to The Guardian’s logotype, it’s bold and striking, use cautiously and appropriatley
Our display typefaces are matched by highly legible text variants
We use our sans serif for small sizes or meta information
We have a colour palette that allows us to be bold, playful, tasteful and sensitive.
Our colour palette is designed to aid readers in navigating therefore consistency is important

Colour is an important tool for both the UI and editorial, each pillar has it’s own colour palette, it contains a main colour, a feature variant and an inverted variant, we also have an extensive neutral palette
Here are our colours
We use various devices to create hierarchy, structure and help people navigate

We have two styles of button. Consider weighting when choosing a style: the lozenge is bolder and the circular button is more subtle. Icons are used to help the user navigate and sit centrally inside an imaginary circle at the edge of the button
We use highlighting to create impact, help aid hierarchy and emphasis within designs
Rules give structure, they also help to add a subtle difference in flavour across articles. We have 4 different types that get used across the website.
